questions.question: In a finite capacity single server queue with exponential arrivals and general distributed service (M/G/1/N), what does 'N' represent?

answers.a: Number of servers in the system
answers.c: Maximum number of customers allowed in the system

explanations.a: Incorrect. 'N' does not represent the number of servers in the system.
explanations.b: Incorrect. 'N' does not represent the arrival rate of customers.
explanations.c: Correct. In the M/G/1/N queueing system, 'N' signifies the maximum number of customers allowed in the system at any given time before new arrivals are rejected.
explanations.d: Incorrect. 'N' does not represent the service rate of the server.

questions.question: In the given queueing model, what distribution is assumed for customer service times?

explanations.a: Correct. In the M/G/1/N queueing model, customer service times are assumed to follow an general distribution.
explanations.b: Incorrect. The M/G/1/N model assumes general distributed service, not specifically a Gaussian distribution.
explanations.c: Incorrect. The M/G/1/N model assumes general distributed service, not specifically a uniform distribution.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The M/G/1/N model assumes general distributed service, not specifically a Poisson distribution.

questions.question: What does the 'M' stand for in the notation M/G/1/N?

answers.d: Minimum number of customers in the system

explanations.a: Correct. In the M/G/1/N notation, 'M' stands for Markovian arrival process.
explanations.b: Incorrect. 'M' does not represent the maximum queue length in the M/G/1/N notation.
explanations.c: Incorrect. 'M' does not represent memoryless service time distribution.
explanations.d: Incorrect. 'M' does not represent the minimum number of customers in the system.

questions.question: If the arrival rate of customers exceeds the service rate of the server in the M/G/1/N queue, what is likely to happen?

answers.d: The server will increase its service rate

explanations.a: Incorrect. If the arrival rate exceeds the service rate, the queue is likely to grow, not empty out quickly.
explanations.b: Incorrect. Customers are likely to stay in the system, contributing to the queue growth.
explanations.c: Correct. When the arrival rate exceeds the service rate, the queue is unable to clear, causing it to grow indefinitely.
explanations.d: Incorrect. The server's service rate does not automatically increase in response to the queue growing due to excess arrivals.
